title: Bought Condo
description: I bought the condo one month before the housing crisis. It lost 33% of its value. When I sold the condo, it had only just regained its value. I bought and sold it for basically the same price a decade apart.

title: Employed by The Elder Scrolls Online
description: Lead Web Developer - Zenimax Online Studios

title: Developer Question of the Week
description: <b-yt slug="4LsEtZdxlLs"></b-yt>

title: Opened The Bronze Coin
description: I opened The Bronze Coin, a role-playing guildhall, after a lot of market research. Pro-DMing was just starting, but had not blossomed as it would during the pandemic. The year+ it operated was tons of fun and work. I met a lot of people who would go on to be part of my life to this day, and many who drifted in pleasantly for years before moving on.

title: Closed The Bronze Coin
description: It turned out that my research was flawed. I'd expected one level of engagement from the people I had interviewed outside game stores, but the reality was 1/10th of what the study indicated. This made the project unsustainable. If I'd opened The Bronze Coin 6-7 years later than I did, I would have missed the pandemic and landed right in the sweet spot of explosive growth in Pro-DMing. Live and learn. Expensive mistake, though.

title: Started Truugahn
description: My first campaign in adulthood was after a long gap since childhood. Though only a little longer than other campaigns, it is deceptive because, unlike the 2-3 hour sessions that happen today, these were often 8-12-hour marathons. We covered in a single session what might be a month's worth of games today. All in all, it was pretty standard fantasy. However, we were on a version of Earth in the deep future. Oh, and some god had cut Earth in half, and the two halves kept their shape magically. (Turns out if you did that, all the water would rush into two big oceans – one on the flat side, and one on the curved side.)

title: Ended Truugahn
description: D&D 4E campaign

title: Started Bonewall
description: D&D 5E campaign

title: Started Comedy of Justice
description:
We all showed up to play D&D, but the apocalypse happened instead. The DM was grabbed by a demon and dragged to Hell, monsters are flying around shooting lasers, and the only weapon anyone can find is a book. This campaign started big and got universal. By the end, one of the players had inherited godhood from Yahweh, another was a Jewish Disney Princess, and another went and learned to fight from Goku. The final battle featured Galactus and Unicron doing the DBZ fusion dance. You had to be there.

The BBEG was Ceres from Evoland 2; why yes, this campaign *did* start before that game came out, and yes, she already was the BBEG before it came out – no, I don't know how, it just happened that way. I played Evoland II and discovered that my BBEG was in it. I don't know how she got there. She *can* open portals between universes. It doesn't seem like it, but I'm being completely serious. Here are my notes about her when she reveals herself as the BBEG to the group. She first met them in session 2, as the Mythomancer, a month before Evoland 2 was released.

"The ceiling tiles melt away, the rails glowing, and a red-hot hole opens in the concrete above. Wreathed in fire, Mytha descends from the floor above, her clothes burned away and her naked body ice blue and covered in black-lined etchings. She has two small black horns on either side of her bald head." Ice-blue-skinned portal-diving universe-hopping demon-girl.

I even named her Mytha when I played Evoland 2 for the first time. I just thought she looked similar; I didn't know who she was yet. When you name her in the game, you wouldn't know she can open portals in time and space.

title: Ended Comedy of Justice
description: D&D 5E campaign

title: Started Isle of Glass Statues
description:
Ultimately, this game had 15 players across four groups. This is the foundation for things to come. Washed up on a deserted island, shifting between obsidian statues and corporal form, players have to survive extreme hostility on an ever-changing landscape.

https://www.reddit.com/r/dndnext/comments/65krnk/isle_of_glass_statues_free_hardcore_multigroup_5e/

title: Started Repocalypse (Comedy of Justice II)
description:
A continuation of Comedy of Justice I with new players - still all playing themselves. Ceres survived the first campaign by living inside me.

If you'd like rules for making universe-hopping games manageable, you can start with my Universe Hopping Rules.docx.

title: Started Halfling Baked
description: Cherry Grass-seed left his band, the Warlocks, over 100 years ago. He's now 270 years old and resolved to go on one last hurrah. The Halfling Bard has hired a half-dozen hale and hearty music lovers (you) as his road crew and loaded up the wagons for the final time.

title: Dale Arnold Review
description:
⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ Bought this expecting modest - Loved it

"I bought this at the dealers room at Balticon because I always try to support new authors. I expected a decent work of course but I enjoyed reading this book more than I have enjoyed Hugo winners in the past. Magic as rules driven physics played as hard science fiction, the human spirit winning out in the end in a clever way. I read all the way through and it did not lag. The author's voice is good. Hope he writes more."

— Dale Arnold, President of the Baltimore Science Fiction Society

title: Started Isle of Glass Statues II
description:
This game was at Dan Wells, Game Night Getaway '24. Dan is the other author on Brandon Sanderson's Intentionally Blank podcast.

The game went exceptionally well. There were 16 players in total over the course of the week, and I got in around 50 hours of play time. They solved the island on the final day.

title: Ended Isle of Glass Statues II
description: D&D 5E campaign

title: Greenlit Unannounced Game
description: I can't say much about this project. It was leaked, so you could find it yourself. I am not at liberty to discuss. However, I can say that the project was extremely personally exciting.

title: Unannounced Game Cancellation
description: RIP

title: Holding everyone together during a project cancellation
description: When the Unannounced Game was cancelled, everyone was devastated. You can look it up by the date. I am not at liberty to name the project, but it was all leaked. Our union Discord server was overrun, with essentially half the company being told to stop working and unsure whether they still had a job. As members of the MC, it fell to us to hold the group together, keep morale up, and get and provide answers.

title: Vote to Unionize
description: In January, we voted. And ZeniMax Online Studios United officially was formed! In a landslide.

title: Running for BC
description: Next, we needed to form our Bargaining Committee (BC), and we had a huge turnout. I narrowly missed being elected to the BC, but the half dozen folks that were elected are all amazing folks who had been part of the OC for a year longer than I'd been.

title: Joining the Organizing Committee
description: Another member of the OC approached me, and I immediately joined the crew. For the next five months, we boned up on how unions work, agitated our coworkers (sounds mean, but this is just union lingo for talking to people about their gripes in the industry and how unions solve them), and built a good foundational infrastructure for our union to hang on when it formed.

title: Campaign to Unionize
description: In October, the campaign proper began. If you don't know, this looks like formally telling your employer that you intend to vote to unionize, having conversations with people to get them to support you, and finally voting together. The OC had to talk to as many of our, at the time, 500 coworkers as possible. In the end, we reached almost all of them, and I personally talked to 200 people.

title: Started Commander Keen
description:
The Commander Keen site is some of my best work to date. The designer I worked with, David Campbell, is top-notch. We worked hand in glove on the designs and had direct access to the game's art director, Marc Hudgins.

From first learning about the game to the website going live, it was just about three months.

title: Announced Commander Keen
description:
Commander Keen Archived Site

The Keen site is a masterpiece. We were so on the bleeding edge.

The game? I loved the aesthetic.

https://www.ign.com/articles/2019/06/10/commander-keen-resurrected-as-a-mobile-game-e3-2019

title: Canceled Commander Keen
